newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tchibo/Eduscho link may pressurise coffee market.
newsitem.headline: Tchibo/Eduscho link may pressurise coffee market.

text.p: German coffee traders said the possible purchase of roaster Eduscho by competitor Tchibo could create a concentration of purchasing power pressurising an increasingly competitive raw materials market.
"It's early days and unclear whether the purchase will be given approval but the two companies might become a very demanding customer," a source at an international trade house said.
"This could, at its worst, lead to lower purchasing prices and narrow traders' margins."
"Retail prices may come under pressure as the competition reacts -- the consumer would benefit from lower prices."
The two companies said they had no plans to merge operations, should the deal be given the go-ahead, but would continue to be run as two separate entities with individual company profiles.

Under the envisaged deal, Tchibo Holding AG, which comprises coffee roasting, consumer goods and cigarettes and is Germany's second largest roaster, would buy Eduscho GmbH & Co KG as of January 1, pending monopoly authority approval.
Eduscho usually is the number three in the market, but in weak periods may slip to number four or five when competitors Melitta Kaffee GmbH and Aldi pursue low-price campaigns.
Eduscho spokesman Rolf Helmbrecht said the move would bring chances to co-ordinate sales of consumer goods, confectionery and drinks, which both companies sell in their tied outlets alongside coffee.
"These sales account for nearly half the turnover and could be raised if synergy was exploited," he said.
"But the two companies' coffee profiles are quite different and may remain so."
Eduscho emphasised fresh coffee at a relatively lower cost than Tchibo which has a higher share of vacuum-packed coffee and has successfully placed expensive gourmet varieties.
Tchibo might be attracted by Eduscho's market leadership in Austria, where it has 150 shops compared with 620 in Germany.
Traders said the move was surprising and likely to worry market leader Jacobs Cafe, which derives its income from coffee alone and accounts for around 30 percent of all sales.
Jacobs, part of Kraft Jacobs Suchard, itself a part of the Philip Morris food group, had no immediate comment.
The move was widely seen as a result of price fights among roasters in the fragmented German market, where sales have fallen sales since 1993 amid flagging consumer confidence.
German coffee association DKV expects green coffee equivalent sales of roasted and soluble coffee this year to be steady at 1995's 564,000 tonnes.
Managing Director Frieder Rotzoll said returns from sales would be sharply lower than 1995's 9.1 billion marks ($1.3 trillion) because retail prices had fallen.
German retail prices per 0.5 kg of roasted coffee averaged seven marks in 1996, broadly in line with Jacobs prices, but they had eased 0.50 marks since January, Jacobs said.
Tchibo products usually cost around one mark more and Eduscho usually ranges between the average and Tchibo.
Among raw materials trends, traders feared the two firms might swap notes about traders and change buying patterns.
The trade, if under pressure from lower buy offers, might look to replace expensive origins with cheaper ones to fulfil orders at lower costs, but this could impair quality.
--Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275 ($ = 1.544 German Marks)
